content: Schedule an appointment with your doctor. If you perceive your ankles to be unusually thick (especially if a sudden change has occurred), then schedule an appointment with your family physician. Your doctor will examine your feet, ankles and legs, ask questions about your family history, diet and lifestyle, and maybe even take your blood pressure or send you for a blood test (to check cholesterol levels). Your doctor will determine if your cankles have a relatively benign cause (such as weight gain or edema from too much dietary salt) or if they are related to a health problem (such as poor circulation or heart disease). However, your family doctor is not a foot or circulatory specialist, so you may need a referral to another doctor with more specialized training. Genetically, some women have naturally larger bones/ankle joints and thicker calf muscles, which cannot be remedied without invasive surgery. Obesity obviously involves fat accumulation around the body, but the face, abdomen, buttocks and thighs are much more common destinations for fat deposit than the ankles. [1] See a specialist about your ankles. If your family doctor thinks your cankles are related to a blood flow problem such as venous insufficiency (a vein condition that causes blood and other fluid to accumulate around the ankle and foot) then you may be referred to a vascular surgeon for a consult. [2] If a hormonal problem is suspected (such as low insulin levels, which is indicative of diabetes), then you may be sent to an endocrinologist. If a heart problem is suspected (such as congestive heart failure), then a cardiologist might be the most appropriate doctor to see and treat your problem. Vascular ultrasound is a painless procedure that allows a doctor to assess the function of the veins and arteries of your lower leg. Podiatrists are foot specialists who may also be helpful in diagnosing ankle problems. Get an accurate diagnosis and understand the cause. Make sure you get the doctor to clearly explain the diagnosis, especially the cause (if possible), and provide you with various treatment options for your cankles. If it's determined that you have no health issues and your larger-than-normal ankles are simply due to genetics and body type, then focus more on body acceptance and overall health, while being less concerned about something as frivolous as the aesthetics of your ankles. Body shapes and sizes can be changed somewhat, but only within well-defined limits. Muscle fiber types and bone structure are inherited characteristics, so losing weight and working out your leg muscles may have very little impact on your cankles. [3] Research the various causes of thick ankles on the internet. It will give you ideas of potential treatments you can do at home, but always stick to reputable medical/health sites. Exercise your legs more. Walking, jogging and cycling are all good exercises that force your lower leg muscles to contract. If you have poor circulation in your legs due to faulty or leaky valves within your veins (a common cause of venous insufficiency), then exercising your lower legs muscles can act like a second heart because they will squeeze the veins and help return the venous blood back into circulation. [4] If you decide to jog, then run on softer surfaces (such as grass) and wear well-cushioned shoes or else you increase the risk of damaging or spraining your ankles and contributing to your problem. Stretching your ankles and lower legs may also promote better blood and lymph flow. Consider taking blood thinners. Fluid accumulation (edema) around the ankles can also be caused by peripheral arterial disease, which occurs when small arteries carrying blood to the legs slowly become narrowed or blocked from plaque accumulation inside the arterial walls -- a disease process called atherosclerosis. [5] Without proper blood flow, the tissues of the foot and ankle don't get enough oxygen and other nutrients and become damaged. With time, the feet and ankles may become inflamed. Taking blood thinners (usually a prescription medication) prevents the plaque build-up in arteries and promotes better blood flow and blood pressure. [6] Commonly recommended blood thinners include aspirin and warfarin (Coumadin). Arterial plaque contains cholesterol, so maintaining a healthy blood cholesterol level may help prevent atherosclerosis. Wear compression stockings. Compression stockings are available online, at medical supply stores, or maybe your medical specialist will give some for free if you're diagnosed with a vascular disease. Compression stockings provide support to muscles and blood vessels, which reduces edema / swelling and promotes better circulation. Putting your feet up while resting, watching TV or sitting at the computer will help with blood flow from your legs due to reducing the effect of gravity. Laying down is even better. Soaking your feet and ankles in a warm Epsom salt bath can significantly reduce pain and swelling. Lose weight by exercising. If your cankles are caused by obesity, then shedding some weight should also help to slim your ankles eventually, as well as improving your overall health status (such as a reduced risk of heart attack and stroke). [7] Depending on your level of obesity, you may want to start with exercises that don't put too much pressure on your ankles and other leg joints, such as swimming or cycling. Once you bring your weight down to safer levels, add weight-bearing exercises such as walking or bouncing on a mini trampoline, which will also promote better blood circulation within your feet and legs. Exercise regimens for obese people should be supervised by a healthcare professional. Fat loss usually occurs from the face and abdomen initially, so be patient for the fat to be burned off from around your ankles. Consider doing some leg exercises that increase the definition of your calves (such as stair climbing) without making the muscles bigger. The enhanced muscle definition may make your ankles appear slimmer. Lose weight by decreasing your caloric consumption. In addition to cardiovascular exercise, focus on reducing the number of calories you consume on a daily basis. Most people who are relatively sedentary only require about 2,000 calories per day to maintain their body processes and have enough energy for mild levels of exercise. Reducing your calorie intake by 500 calories daily will result in about 4 pounds of fat tissue loss per month. Salads made with leafy greens and fresh vegetables are excellent choices for weight loss because they are low-calorie, high in nutrients and relatively bulky (high in fiber), so they fill up your stomach. Just remember to go easy on the salad dressing. Drinking lots of water is great for weight loss because it's calorie free and helps to curb your appetite. Consider liposuction. If you're having trouble losing the fat deposits around your ankle, then schedule a consultation with a vascular or cosmetic surgeon in order to discuss fat removal via liposuction. [8] Being invasive, surgery should be your last option to combat your cankles, not your first choice because of the potential convenience. In addition to liposuction, the surgeon may be able to shave or remodel the bones and muscles of the lower calf and ankle. Make sure you understand all the risks of undergoing surgery, such as allergic reactions to anesthesia, infections and heavy blood loss. Reduce your dietary salt intake. Diets high in salt tend to make tissues look puffy because the sodium within salt pulls the water from the cells into the surrounding interstitial spaces, creating a type of swelling called edema. [9] The face, hands and feet/ankles are common areas affected by high-salt diets. Most processed foods are high in sodium, so focus more on fresh meats and produce. Canned tomato sauces, salsas, crackers and pickled veggies are particularly high in sodium. Your daily sodium intake should be between 1,500 mg and 2,300 mg. [10] A low-sodium diet recommended by many doctors is called the DASH diet. [11] Be patient if you're pregnant. Pregnancy not only involves weight gain that may negatively impact your ankles, but also periods of poor circulation and changes in hormonal levels, which often promotes fluid retention in the lower legs. So if you're worried about your cankles during pregnancy, then you can certainly reduce your sodium intake, but simply wait until you give birth and see if your ankles go back to normal size. Going on moderately paced walks and always raising your legs when you sit will help reduce edema in your ankles while you're pregnant. Realize also that edema can come and go with a woman's menstrual cycle. [12] Avoid consuming excessive alcohol, especially beer. Chronic alcohol intake can injury the pancreas and liver because ethanol is relatively toxic. A damaged liver doesn't work properly making enzymes and processing amino acids, which leads to edema (water retention) in the body. [13] Alcohol is also fairly high in sugar-based calories (especially when combined with soda pop) without containing any other nutrients, which promotes weight gain. Beer can be particularly problematic because some brands are also high in sodium. Consider switching to red wine, which is healthier for your blood vessels. [14] Avoid eating the peanuts and pretzels that are served at some bars, as both are very high in salt. Wear long, wide-legged pants. Long pants will cover your cankles and slim your legs at the same time. Wide-legged styles are best, as these don’t hug your ankles. Try to avoid skinny jeans and cropped styles that cut off right above the ankle. [15] Long dresses and skirts also have a slimming effect. Just make sure they cut off at the ankle, not above it. Choose high-waisted bottoms. High-waisted bottoms lengthen your legs, resulting in a slimmer-looking ankle. Try high-waisted pants or a long, high-waisted skirt. [16] Pick chunky heels. Chunky heels can make large ankles look slimmer. Stay away from stilettos, which are small and thin, making your ankles look larger in comparison. [17] Avoid shoes with ankle straps. Ankle straps will only call attention to your cankles. Instead, pick shoes that cover your ankles, like high boots, or shoes with pointed toes, which help elongate your legs. [18] Draw attention elsewhere with accessories. If you don’t want to give up cropped pants or sandals with ankle straps, try accessorizing. Bold accessories, like handbags, sunglasses, and jewelry, will draw eyes upward and away from your cankles. [19]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Get-Rid-of-Cankles">How to Get Rid of Cankles</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Michele Dolan</a>
</div>

<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>

<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=micheledolan#micheledolan">Michele Dolan</a>. Michele Dolan is a BCRPA certified Personal Trainer in British Columbia. She has been a personal trainer and fitness instructor since 2002.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">19 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Cankles, a contraction from the term "calf-ankles," refers to chubby ankles with poor definition or a lack of distinction from where the lower part of the calf muscle terminates and the ankle joint begins. Cankles is not a medical term, but rather a derogatory term usually reserved for describing women's thick ankles. A variety of factors and conditions contribute to the formation of cankles such as genetics (perhaps the most common), obesity, diabetes, hypertension, heart disease and lymphedema. Minimizing or getting rid of cankles is dependent on their cause. Cankles caused by health conditions tend to be much more treatable than those dictated by genetic factors.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Determining_The_Cause_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Determining_The_Cause">Determining The Cause</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_262c5b7c72" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_262c5b7c72')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Schedule an appointment with your doctor.</b> If you perceive your ankles to be unusually thick (especially if a sudden change has occurred), then schedule an appointment with your family physician. Your doctor will examine your feet, ankles and legs, ask questions about your family history, diet and lifestyle, and maybe even take your blood pressure or send you for a blood test (to check cholesterol levels). Your doctor will determine if your cankles have a relatively benign cause (such as weight gain or edema from too much dietary salt) or if they are related to a health problem (such as poor circulation or heart disease). However, your family doctor is not a foot or circulatory specialist, so you may need a referral to another doctor with more specialized training.

<ul>
<li>Genetically, some women have naturally larger bones/ankle joints and thicker calf muscles, which cannot be remedied without invasive surgery.</li>
<li>Obesity obviously involves fat accumulation around the body, but the face, abdomen, buttocks and thighs are much more common destinations for fat deposit than the ankles.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4bb5c3928c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4bb5c3928c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See a specialist about your ankles.</b> If your family doctor thinks your cankles are related to a blood flow problem such as venous insufficiency (a vein condition that causes blood and other fluid to accumulate around the ankle and foot) then you may be referred to a vascular surgeon for a consult.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> If a hormonal problem is suspected (such as low insulin levels, which is indicative of diabetes), then you may be sent to an endocrinologist. If a heart problem is suspected (such as congestive heart failure), then a cardiologist might be the most appropriate doctor to see and treat your problem.

<ul>
<li>Vascular ultrasound is a painless procedure that allows a doctor to assess the function of the veins and arteries of your lower leg.</li>
<li>Podiatrists are foot specialists who may also be helpful in diagnosing ankle problems.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_b0efdc1b42" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b0efdc1b42')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get an accurate diagnosis and understand the cause.</b> Make sure you get the doctor to clearly explain the diagnosis, especially the cause (if possible), and provide you with various treatment options for your cankles. If it's determined that you have no health issues and your larger-than-normal ankles are simply due to genetics and body type, then focus more on body acceptance and overall health, while being less concerned about something as frivolous as the aesthetics of your ankles. Body shapes and sizes can be changed somewhat, but only within well-defined limits.

<ul>
<li>Muscle fiber types and bone structure are inherited characteristics, so losing weight and working out your leg muscles may have very little impact on your cankles.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Research the various causes of thick ankles on the internet. It will give you ideas of potential treatments you can do at home, but always stick to reputable medical/health sites.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Combating_Vascular_Disease_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Combating_Vascular_Disease">Combating Vascular Disease</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_768957020c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_768957020c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Exercise your legs more.</b> Walking, jogging and cycling are all good exercises that force your lower leg muscles to contract. If you have poor circulation in your legs due to faulty or leaky valves within your veins (a common cause of venous insufficiency), then exercising your lower legs muscles can act like a second heart because they will squeeze the veins and help return the venous blood back into circulation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you decide to jog, then run on softer surfaces (such as grass) and wear well-cushioned shoes or else you increase the risk of damaging or spraining your ankles and contributing to your problem.</li>
<li>Stretching your ankles and lower legs may also promote better blood and lymph flow.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_7ccb8f1f3b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7ccb8f1f3b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider taking blood thinners.</b> Fluid accumulation (edema) around the ankles can also be caused by peripheral arterial disease, which occurs when small arteries carrying blood to the legs slowly become narrowed or blocked from plaque accumulation inside the arterial walls -- a disease process called atherosclerosis.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Without proper blood flow, the tissues of the foot and ankle don't get enough oxygen and other nutrients and become damaged. With time, the feet and ankles may become inflamed. Taking blood thinners (usually a prescription medication) prevents the plaque build-up in arteries and promotes better blood flow and blood pressure.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Commonly recommended blood thinners include aspirin and warfarin (Coumadin).</li>
<li>Arterial plaque contains cholesterol, so maintaining a healthy blood cholesterol level may help prevent atherosclerosis.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_57a5aad273" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_57a5aad273')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wear compression stockings.</b> Compression stockings are available online, at medical supply stores, or maybe your medical specialist will give some for free if you're diagnosed with a vascular disease. Compression stockings provide support to muscles and blood vessels, which reduces edema / swelling and promotes better circulation.

<ul>
<li>Putting your feet up while resting, watching TV or sitting at the computer will help with blood flow from your legs due to reducing the effect of gravity. Laying down is even better.</li>
<li>Soaking your feet and ankles in a warm Epsom salt bath can significantly reduce pain and swelling.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Combating_Obesity_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Combating_Obesity">Combating Obesity</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_39a8b0d347" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_39a8b0d347')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Lose weight by exercising.</b> If your cankles are caused by obesity, then shedding some weight should also help to slim your ankles eventually, as well as improving your overall health status (such as a reduced risk of heart attack and stroke).<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Depending on your level of obesity, you may want to start with exercises that don't put too much pressure on your ankles and other leg joints, such as swimming or cycling. Once you bring your weight down to safer levels, add weight-bearing exercises such as walking or bouncing on a mini trampoline, which will also promote better blood circulation within your feet and legs.

<ul>
<li>Exercise regimens for obese people should be supervised by a healthcare professional.</li>
<li>Fat loss usually occurs from the face and abdomen initially, so be patient for the fat to be burned off from around your ankles.</li>
<li>Consider doing some leg exercises that increase the definition of your calves (such as stair climbing) without making the muscles bigger. The enhanced muscle definition may make your ankles appear slimmer.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_2f9e77ee59" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2f9e77ee59')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Lose weight by decreasing your caloric consumption.</b> In addition to cardiovascular exercise, focus on reducing the number of calories you consume on a daily basis. Most people who are relatively sedentary only require about 2,000 calories per day to maintain their body processes and have enough energy for mild levels of exercise. Reducing your calorie intake by 500 calories daily will result in about 4 pounds of fat tissue loss per month.

<ul>
<li>Salads made with leafy greens and fresh vegetables are excellent choices for weight loss because they are low-calorie, high in nutrients and relatively bulky (high in fiber), so they fill up your stomach. Just remember to go easy on the salad dressing.</li>
<li>Drinking lots of water is great for weight loss because it's calorie free and helps to curb your appetite.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_62a264dcf5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_62a264dcf5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider liposuction.</b> If you're having trouble losing the fat deposits around your ankle, then schedule a consultation with a vascular or cosmetic surgeon in order to discuss fat removal via liposuction.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Being invasive, surgery should be your last option to combat your cankles, not your first choice because of the potential convenience. In addition to liposuction, the surgeon may be able to shave or remodel the bones and muscles of the lower calf and ankle.

<ul>
<li>Make sure you understand all the risks of undergoing surgery, such as allergic reactions to anesthesia, infections and heavy blood loss.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Combating_Water_Retention_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Combating_Water_Retention">Combating Water Retention</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_79b9e47b28" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_79b9e47b28')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Reduce your dietary salt intake.</b> Diets high in salt tend to make tissues look puffy because the sodium within salt pulls the water from the cells into the surrounding interstitial spaces, creating a type of swelling called edema.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup> The face, hands and feet/ankles are common areas affected by high-salt diets. Most processed foods are high in sodium, so focus more on fresh meats and produce.

<ul>
<li>Canned tomato sauces, salsas, crackers and pickled veggies are particularly high in sodium. Your daily sodium intake should be between 1,500 mg and 2,300 mg.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>A low-sodium diet recommended by many doctors is called the DASH diet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_4e98a5d0d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4e98a5d0d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be patient if you're pregnant.</b> Pregnancy not only involves weight gain that may negatively impact your ankles, but also periods of poor circulation and changes in hormonal levels, which often promotes fluid retention in the lower legs. So if you're worried about your cankles during pregnancy, then you can certainly reduce your sodium intake, but simply wait until you give birth and see if your ankles go back to normal size.

<ul>
<li>Going on moderately paced walks and always raising your legs when you sit will help reduce edema in your ankles while you're pregnant.</li>
<li>Realize also that edema can come and go with a woman's menstrual cycle.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_574d2bd8d7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_574d2bd8d7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Cankles Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1a/Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Cankles-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid consuming excessive alcohol, especially beer.</b> Chronic alcohol intake can injury the pancreas and liver because ethanol is relatively toxic. A damaged liver doesn't work properly making enzymes and processing amino acids, which leads to edema (water retention) in the body.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Alcohol is also fairly high in sugar-based calories (especially when combined with soda pop) without containing any other nutrients, which promotes weight gain. Beer can be particularly problematic because some brands are also high in sodium.

<ul>
<li>Consider switching to red wine, which is healthier for your blood vessels.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Avoid eating the peanuts and pretzels that are served at some bars, as both are very high in salt.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Dressing_to_Make_Cankles_Look_Smaller_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>5</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Dressing_to_Make_Cankles_Look_Smaller">Dressing to Make Cankles Look Smaller</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_5">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stretch the Waistline of Your Pants Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f8c5521c3e" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f8c5521c3e')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stretch the Waistline of Your Pants Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Stretch-the-Waistline-of-Your-Pants-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wear long, wide-legged pants.</b> Long pants will cover your cankles and slim your legs at the same time. Wide-legged styles are best, as these don’t hug your ankles. Try to avoid skinny jeans and cropped styles that cut off right above the ankle.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Long dresses and skirts also have a slimming effect. Just make sure they cut off at the ankle, not above it.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Dress in the American 1950s Fashion Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a0c257c8e5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a0c257c8e5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Dress in the American 1950s Fashion Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Dress-in-the-American-1950s-Fashion-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose high-waisted bottoms.</b> High-waisted bottoms lengthen your legs, resulting in a slimmer-looking ankle. Try high-waisted pants or a long, high-waisted skirt.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Choose High Heels Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_83d80889da" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_83d80889da')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Choose High Heels Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Choose-High-Heels-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pick chunky heels.</b> Chunky heels can make large ankles look slimmer. Stay away from stilettos, which are small and thin, making your ankles look larger in comparison.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Select Shoes to Wear with an Outfit Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_f682038467" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f682038467')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Select Shoes to Wear with an Outfit Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Select-Shoes-to-Wear-with-an-Outfit-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid shoes with ankle straps.</b> Ankle straps will only call attention to your cankles. Instead, pick shoes that cover your ankles, like high boots, or shoes with pointed toes, which help elongate your legs.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=3311809" href="#/Image:Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Dress for the Club Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_6ceb8718a2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6ceb8718a2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Dress for the Club Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid3311809-v4-728px-Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_5_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Draw attention elsewhere with accessories.</b> If you don’t want to give up cropped pants or sandals with ankle straps, try accessorizing. Bold accessories, like handbags, sunglasses, and jewelry, will draw eyes upward and away from your cankles.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="3311809" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="277701" data-caid="278574" data-cqid="277718" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="512857" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="5476" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="9">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I'm skinny, but I have cankles. Does that mean I'm fat? I want slim ankles.</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=micheledolan#micheledolan" target="_blank">
<span>MD</span></a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=micheledolan#micheledolan" target="_blank">Michele Dolan</a><br/>
	Certified Personal Trainer
</div>
Michele Dolan is a BCRPA certified Personal Trainer in British Columbia. She has been a personal trainer and fitness instructor since 2002.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=micheledolan#micheledolan" target="_blank">
<span>MD</span></a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=micheledolan#micheledolan" target="_blank">Michele Dolan</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Certified Personal Trainer</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Having cankles doesn't mean you are fat. If you are not overweight, your cankles are probably genetic. Try jumping rope to make your ankles look smaller. Jumping exercises build up muscle in your calves, making your ankles look smaller in comparison.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>2</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>9</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Spot training an area to lose weight there doesn't work. Thus, exercising your entire body will lose weight from your ankles faster than just focusing on movements that target your lower legs.</li>
<li>Weight training is typically better for losing weight than cardiovascular exercise.</li>
<li>The estrogen contained in birth control pills can cause swelling in some women's ankles and legs.</li>
</ul>

}</script><script type="application/ld+json">{
    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Get Rid of Cankles",
    "name": "Get Rid of Cankles",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Get-Rid-of-Cankles"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/9\/96\/Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\/aid3311809-v4-1200px-Dress-for-the-Club-Step-9-Version-2.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 119,
        "ratingValue": 83
    },
    "datePublished": "2013-09-03",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Michele Dolan"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Determining The Cause",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Schedule an appointment with your doctor. If you perceive your ankles to be unusually thick (especially if a sudden change has occurred), then schedule an appointment with your family physician. Your doctor will examine your feet, ankles and legs, ask questions about your family history, diet and lifestyle, and maybe even take your blood pressure or send you for a blood test (to check cholesterol levels). Your doctor will determine if your cankles have a relatively benign cause (such as weight gain or edema from too much dietary salt) or if they are related to a health problem (such as poor circulation or heart disease). However, your family doctor is not a foot or circulatory specialist, so you may need a referral to another doctor with more specialized training.\n\nGenetically, some women have naturally larger bones\/ankle joints and thicker calf muscles, which cannot be remedied without invasive surgery.\nObesity obviously involves fat accumulation around the body, but the face, abdomen, buttocks and thighs are much more common destinations for fat deposit than the ankles.[1]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "See a specialist about your ankles. If your family doctor thinks your cankles are related to a blood flow problem such as venous insufficiency (a vein condition that causes blood and other fluid to accumulate around the ankle and foot) then you may be referred to a vascular surgeon for a consult.[2] If a hormonal problem is suspected (such as low insulin levels, which is indicative of diabetes), then you may be sent to an endocrinologist. If a heart problem is suspected (such as congestive heart failure), then a cardiologist might be the most appropriate doctor to see and treat your problem.\n\nVascular ultrasound is a painless procedure that allows a doctor to assess the function of the veins and arteries of your lower leg.\nPodiatrists are foot specialists who may also be helpful in diagnosing ankle problems."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Get an accurate diagnosis and understand the cause. Make sure you get the doctor to clearly explain the diagnosis, especially the cause (if possible), and provide you with various treatment options for your cankles. If it's determined that you have no health issues and your larger-than-normal ankles are simply due to genetics and body type, then focus more on body acceptance and overall health, while being less concerned about something as frivolous as the aesthetics of your ankles. Body shapes and sizes can be changed somewhat, but only within well-defined limits.\n\nMuscle fiber types and bone structure are inherited characteristics, so losing weight and working out your leg muscles may have very little impact on your cankles.[3]\nResearch the various causes of thick ankles on the internet. It will give you ideas of potential treatments you can do at home, but always stick to reputable medical\/health sites."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Combating Vascular Disease",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Exercise your legs more. Walking, jogging and cycling are all good exercises that force your lower leg muscles to contract. If you have poor circulation in your legs due to faulty or leaky valves within your veins (a common cause of venous insufficiency), then exercising your lower legs muscles can act like a second heart because they will squeeze the veins and help return the venous blood back into circulation.[4]\nIf you decide to jog, then run on softer surfaces (such as grass) and wear well-cushioned shoes or else you increase the risk of damaging or spraining your ankles and contributing to your problem.\nStretching your ankles and lower legs may also promote better blood and lymph flow."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider taking blood thinners. Fluid accumulation (edema) around the ankles can also be caused by peripheral arterial disease, which occurs when small arteries carrying blood to the legs slowly become narrowed or blocked from plaque accumulation inside the arterial walls -- a disease process called atherosclerosis.[5] Without proper blood flow, the tissues of the foot and ankle don't get enough oxygen and other nutrients and become damaged. With time, the feet and ankles may become inflamed. Taking blood thinners (usually a prescription medication) prevents the plaque build-up in arteries and promotes better blood flow and blood pressure.[6]\nCommonly recommended blood thinners include aspirin and warfarin (Coumadin).\nArterial plaque contains cholesterol, so maintaining a healthy blood cholesterol level may help prevent atherosclerosis."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wear compression stockings. Compression stockings are available online, at medical supply stores, or maybe your medical specialist will give some for free if you're diagnosed with a vascular disease. Compression stockings provide support to muscles and blood vessels, which reduces edema \/ swelling and promotes better circulation.\n\nPutting your feet up while resting, watching TV or sitting at the computer will help with blood flow from your legs due to reducing the effect of gravity. Laying down is even better.\nSoaking your feet and ankles in a warm Epsom salt bath can significantly reduce pain and swelling."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Combating Obesity",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Lose weight by exercising. If your cankles are caused by obesity, then shedding some weight should also help to slim your ankles eventually, as well as improving your overall health status (such as a reduced risk of heart attack and stroke).[7] Depending on your level of obesity, you may want to start with exercises that don't put too much pressure on your ankles and other leg joints, such as swimming or cycling. Once you bring your weight down to safer levels, add weight-bearing exercises such as walking or bouncing on a mini trampoline, which will also promote better blood circulation within your feet and legs.\n\nExercise regimens for obese people should be supervised by a healthcare professional.\nFat loss usually occurs from the face and abdomen initially, so be patient for the fat to be burned off from around your ankles.\nConsider doing some leg exercises that increase the definition of your calves (such as stair climbing) without making the muscles bigger. The enhanced muscle definition may make your ankles appear slimmer."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Lose weight by decreasing your caloric consumption. In addition to cardiovascular exercise, focus on reducing the number of calories you consume on a daily basis. Most people who are relatively sedentary only require about 2,000 calories per day to maintain their body processes and have enough energy for mild levels of exercise. Reducing your calorie intake by 500 calories daily will result in about 4 pounds of fat tissue loss per month.\n\nSalads made with leafy greens and fresh vegetables are excellent choices for weight loss because they are low-calorie, high in nutrients and relatively bulky (high in fiber), so they fill up your stomach. Just remember to go easy on the salad dressing.\nDrinking lots of water is great for weight loss because it's calorie free and helps to curb your appetite."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider liposuction. If you're having trouble losing the fat deposits around your ankle, then schedule a consultation with a vascular or cosmetic surgeon in order to discuss fat removal via liposuction.[8] Being invasive, surgery should be your last option to combat your cankles, not your first choice because of the potential convenience. In addition to liposuction, the surgeon may be able to shave or remodel the bones and muscles of the lower calf and ankle.\n\nMake sure you understand all the risks of undergoing surgery, such as allergic reactions to anesthesia, infections and heavy blood loss."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Combating Water Retention",
            "position": 4,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Reduce your dietary salt intake. Diets high in salt tend to make tissues look puffy because the sodium within salt pulls the water from the cells into the surrounding interstitial spaces, creating a type of swelling called edema.[9] The face, hands and feet\/ankles are common areas affected by high-salt diets. Most processed foods are high in sodium, so focus more on fresh meats and produce.\n\nCanned tomato sauces, salsas, crackers and pickled veggies are particularly high in sodium. Your daily sodium intake should be between 1,500 mg and 2,300 mg.[10]\nA low-sodium diet recommended by many doctors is called the DASH diet.[11]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Be patient if you're pregnant. Pregnancy not only involves weight gain that may negatively impact your ankles, but also periods of poor circulation and changes in hormonal levels, which often promotes fluid retention in the lower legs. So if you're worried about your cankles during pregnancy, then you can certainly reduce your sodium intake, but simply wait until you give birth and see if your ankles go back to normal size.\n\nGoing on moderately paced walks and always raising your legs when you sit will help reduce edema in your ankles while you're pregnant.\nRealize also that edema can come and go with a woman's menstrual cycle.[12]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid consuming excessive alcohol, especially beer. Chronic alcohol intake can injury the pancreas and liver because ethanol is relatively toxic. A damaged liver doesn't work properly making enzymes and processing amino acids, which leads to edema (water retention) in the body.[13] Alcohol is also fairly high in sugar-based calories (especially when combined with soda pop) without containing any other nutrients, which promotes weight gain. Beer can be particularly problematic because some brands are also high in sodium.\n\nConsider switching to red wine, which is healthier for your blood vessels.[14]\nAvoid eating the peanuts and pretzels that are served at some bars, as both are very high in salt."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Dressing to Make Cankles Look Smaller",
            "position": 5,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wear long, wide-legged pants. Long pants will cover your cankles and slim your legs at the same time. Wide-legged styles are best, as these don\u2019t hug your ankles. Try to avoid skinny jeans and cropped styles that cut off right above the ankle.[15]\nLong dresses and skirts also have a slimming effect. Just make sure they cut off at the ankle, not above it."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose high-waisted bottoms. High-waisted bottoms lengthen your legs, resulting in a slimmer-looking ankle. Try high-waisted pants or a long, high-waisted skirt.[16]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Pick chunky heels. Chunky heels can make large ankles look slimmer. Stay away from stilettos, which are small and thin, making your ankles look larger in comparison.[17]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid shoes with ankle straps. Ankle straps will only call attention to your cankles. Instead, pick shoes that cover your ankles, like high boots, or shoes with pointed toes, which help elongate your legs.[18]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,

title: How to Get Rid of Cankles
content_html:
Schedule an appointment with your doctor. If you perceive your ankles to be unusually thick (especially if a sudden change has occurred), then schedule an appointment with your family physician. Your doctor will examine your feet, ankles and legs, ask questions about your family history, diet and lifestyle, and maybe even take your blood pressure or send you for a blood test (to check cholesterol levels). Your doctor will determine if your cankles have a relatively benign cause (such as weight gain or edema from too much dietary salt) or if they are related to a health problem (such as poor circulation or heart disease). However, your family doctor is not a foot or circulatory specialist, so you may need a referral to another doctor with more specialized training.
  • Genetically, some women have naturally larger bones/ankle joints and thicker calf muscles, which cannot be remedied without invasive surgery.
  • Obesity obviously involves fat accumulation around the body, but the face, abdomen, buttocks and thighs are much more common destinations for fat deposit than the ankles.[1]
See a specialist about your ankles. If your family doctor thinks your cankles are related to a blood flow problem such as venous insufficiency (a vein condition that causes blood and other fluid to accumulate around the ankle and foot) then you may be referred to a vascular surgeon for a consult.[2] If a hormonal problem is suspected (such as low insulin levels, which is indicative of diabetes), then you may be sent to an endocrinologist. If a heart problem is suspected (such as congestive heart failure), then a cardiologist might be the most appropriate doctor to see and treat your problem.
  • Vascular ultrasound is a painless procedure that allows a doctor to assess the function of the veins and arteries of your lower leg.
  • Podiatrists are foot specialists who may also be helpful in diagnosing ankle problems.
Get an accurate diagnosis and understand the cause. Make sure you get the doctor to clearly explain the diagnosis, especially the cause (if possible), and provide you with various treatment options for your cankles. If it's determined that you have no health issues and your larger-than-normal ankles are simply due to genetics and body type, then focus more on body acceptance and overall health, while being less concerned about something as frivolous as the aesthetics of your ankles. Body shapes and sizes can be changed somewhat, but only within well-defined limits.
  • Muscle fiber types and bone structure are inherited characteristics, so losing weight and working out your leg muscles may have very little impact on your cankles.[3]
  • Research the various causes of thick ankles on the internet. It will give you ideas of potential treatments you can do at home, but always stick to reputable medical/health sites.
Exercise your legs more. Walking, jogging and cycling are all good exercises that force your lower leg muscles to contract. If you have poor circulation in your legs due to faulty or leaky valves within your veins (a common cause of venous insufficiency), then exercising your lower legs muscles can act like a second heart because they will squeeze the veins and help return the venous blood back into circulation.[4]
  • If you decide to jog, then run on softer surfaces (such as grass) and wear well-cushioned shoes or else you increase the risk of damaging or spraining your ankles and contributing to your problem.
  • Stretching your ankles and lower legs may also promote better blood and lymph flow.
Consider taking blood thinners. Fluid accumulation (edema) around the ankles can also be caused by peripheral arterial disease, which occurs when small arteries carrying blood to the legs slowly become narrowed or blocked from plaque accumulation inside the arterial walls -- a disease process called atherosclerosis.[5] Without proper blood flow, the tissues of the foot and ankle don't get enough oxygen and other nutrients and become damaged. With time, the feet and ankles may become inflamed. Taking blood thinners (usually a prescription medication) prevents the plaque build-up in arteries and promotes better blood flow and blood pressure.[6]
  • Commonly recommended blood thinners include aspirin and warfarin (Coumadin).
  • Arterial plaque contains cholesterol, so maintaining a healthy blood cholesterol level may help prevent atherosclerosis.
Wear compression stockings. Compression stockings are available online, at medical supply stores, or maybe your medical specialist will give some for free if you're diagnosed with a vascular disease. Compression stockings provide support to muscles and blood vessels, which reduces edema / swelling and promotes better circulation.
  • Putting your feet up while resting, watching TV or sitting at the computer will help with blood flow from your legs due to reducing the effect of gravity. Laying down is even better.
  • Soaking your feet and ankles in a warm Epsom salt bath can significantly reduce pain and swelling.
Lose weight by exercising. If your cankles are caused by obesity, then shedding some weight should also help to slim your ankles eventually, as well as improving your overall health status (such as a reduced risk of heart attack and stroke).[7] Depending on your level of obesity, you may want to start with exercises that don't put too much pressure on your ankles and other leg joints, such as swimming or cycling. Once you bring your weight down to safer levels, add weight-bearing exercises such as walking or bouncing on a mini trampoline, which will also promote better blood circulation within your feet and legs.
  • Exercise regimens for obese people should be supervised by a healthcare professional.
  • Fat loss usually occurs from the face and abdomen initially, so be patient for the fat to be burned off from around your ankles.
  • Consider doing some leg exercises that increase the definition of your calves (such as stair climbing) without making the muscles bigger. The enhanced muscle definition may make your ankles appear slimmer.
Lose weight by decreasing your caloric consumption. In addition to cardiovascular exercise, focus on reducing the number of calories you consume on a daily basis. Most people who are relatively sedentary only require about 2,000 calories per day to maintain their body processes and have enough energy for mild levels of exercise. Reducing your calorie intake by 500 calories daily will result in about 4 pounds of fat tissue loss per month.
  • Salads made with leafy greens and fresh vegetables are excellent choices for weight loss because they are low-calorie, high in nutrients and relatively bulky (high in fiber), so they fill up your stomach. Just remember to go easy on the salad dressing.
  • Drinking lots of water is great for weight loss because it's calorie free and helps to curb your appetite.
Consider liposuction. If you're having trouble losing the fat deposits around your ankle, then schedule a consultation with a vascular or cosmetic surgeon in order to discuss fat removal via liposuction.[8] Being invasive, surgery should be your last option to combat your cankles, not your first choice because of the potential convenience. In addition to liposuction, the surgeon may be able to shave or remodel the bones and muscles of the lower calf and ankle.
  • Make sure you understand all the risks of undergoing surgery, such as allergic reactions to anesthesia, infections and heavy blood loss.
Reduce your dietary salt intake. Diets high in salt tend to make tissues look puffy because the sodium within salt pulls the water from the cells into the surrounding interstitial spaces, creating a type of swelling called edema.[9] The face, hands and feet/ankles are common areas affected by high-salt diets. Most processed foods are high in sodium, so focus more on fresh meats and produce.
  • Canned tomato sauces, salsas, crackers and pickled veggies are particularly high in sodium. Your daily sodium intake should be between 1,500 mg and 2,300 mg.[10]
  • A low-sodium diet recommended by many doctors is called the DASH diet.[11]
Be patient if you're pregnant. Pregnancy not only involves weight gain that may negatively impact your ankles, but also periods of poor circulation and changes in hormonal levels, which often promotes fluid retention in the lower legs. So if you're worried about your cankles during pregnancy, then you can certainly reduce your sodium intake, but simply wait until you give birth and see if your ankles go back to normal size.
  • Going on moderately paced walks and always raising your legs when you sit will help reduce edema in your ankles while you're pregnant.
  • Realize also that edema can come and go with a woman's menstrual cycle.[12]
Avoid consuming excessive alcohol, especially beer. Chronic alcohol intake can injury the pancreas and liver because ethanol is relatively toxic. A damaged liver doesn't work properly making enzymes and processing amino acids, which leads to edema (water retention) in the body.[13] Alcohol is also fairly high in sugar-based calories (especially when combined with soda pop) without containing any other nutrients, which promotes weight gain. Beer can be particularly problematic because some brands are also high in sodium.
  • Consider switching to red wine, which is healthier for your blood vessels.[14]
  • Avoid eating the peanuts and pretzels that are served at some bars, as both are very high in salt.
Wear long, wide-legged pants. Long pants will cover your cankles and slim your legs at the same time. Wide-legged styles are best, as these don’t hug your ankles. Try to avoid skinny jeans and cropped styles that cut off right above the ankle.[15]
  • Long dresses and skirts also have a slimming effect. Just make sure they cut off at the ankle, not above it.
Choose high-waisted bottoms. High-waisted bottoms lengthen your legs, resulting in a slimmer-looking ankle. Try high-waisted pants or a long, high-waisted skirt.[16]
Pick chunky heels. Chunky heels can make large ankles look slimmer. Stay away from stilettos, which are small and thin, making your ankles look larger in comparison.[17]
Avoid shoes with ankle straps. Ankle straps will only call attention to your cankles. Instead, pick shoes that cover your ankles, like high boots, or shoes with pointed toes, which help elongate your legs.[18]
Draw attention elsewhere with accessories. If you don’t want to give up cropped pants or sandals with ankle straps, try accessorizing. Bold accessories, like handbags, sunglasses, and jewelry, will draw eyes upward and away from your cankles.[19]
